title: Ayla Hauser
text: Ayla Hauser is a student at Smith College. She is a neuroscience major and data science minor. When not attending classes, she enjoys competing on the Smith College Tennis Team and reading.

title: Ayla Hauser
text:

Please let me know if the above times do not work for your schedule and we can coordinate another time.

title: 1st_Maps
text:
#install.packages("maps")
library(maps)
Here are some maps from the map package. 1

title: 1st_Maps
text:
The US

maps::map(database = "state")









map(database = "state", regions = "Massachusetts")









map(database = "county", regions = c("Massachusetts"))
map.cities()









new_england <-c('Vermont',"Massachusetts","Connecticut", "Rhode Island", "New Hampshire", "Maine")

map(database = "county", regions = new_england)
map.cities()









west_coast <-c("California","Oregon","Washington")

colors <-c('blue', 'pink', 'orange', 'yellow')

map(database = "state", regions = west_coast, col = colors, fill = TRUE)









map(regions = c( "China" , "Indonesia" , "Australia"))








You try:
First maps

Add another map of California, Oregon and Washington.

Color this map. hint: type ?map() into the console to read the documentation.

Color the map with three colors of your choice.
Color the border only.


Make a world map with China, Indonesia and Australia.

title: Fancier Maps
text:
We can use leaflet to make some fancier maps.

#install.packages(leaflet)
library(leaflet)

Manual here Here is a text on leaflet.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles()




?leaflet()

starting httpd help server ... done


Let’s put Smith College on the map. Here’s the lat and long.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = 72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")





Whooops. We need a negative sign to indicate west.

leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College")






#we made regular markers for smith and hometown, then added awesome markers to get the school and home icons. 
home_icon <- awesomeIcons()
school_icon <- awesomeIcons(icon = "education")

#this is the code that makes the two markers with awesome icons on the map. Remember to use pipe and commas. 
leaflet()|>
  addTiles() |>
  addAwesomeMarkers(lng = -83.9207,
             lat = 35.9606, 
             popup = "My Home",
             label = "Knoxville",
             icon = home_icon
             ) |>
 addAwesomeMarkers(lng = -72.6403,
             lat = 42.3163,
             popup = "Home of the Pioneers",
             label = "Smith College", 
             icon = school_icon
             ) 





You try:

Put your home city and Smith College on the same map.
Use awesomeIcons() to make your home look like a home and smith look like a college.

You will first need to save the icon an object. (Maybe the home is called home).
Hint: Use icon “education”, “book”, “sleeping” for the college icon.
Then you will need to use addAwesomeMarkers().

Finally add this webpage to your index.qmd and make sure it renders correctly.
